structured_info.title_cn: 高速公路自动驾驶专用车道纵向和横向位置的联合优化
structured_info.title_en: Joint Optimization of Longitudinal and Lateral Locations of Autonomous-Vehicle-Dedicated Lanes on Expressways
structured_info.abstract: Appropriate deployment of autonomous-vehicle-dedicated lanes (AVDLs) is crucial for optimizing transportation system with mixed human-driven and autonomous vehicles. Existing studies mainly focus on matching the capacity and traffic flow volume to maximize throughput under different AV penetration rate, while lane changing scenarios and network geometry impacts were ignored. Therefore, the lateral locations in optimal deployment on expressway cannot be determined. This study developed an analysis framework to jointly optimize the longitudinal and lateral locations of AVDLs on expressways. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization model. In the lower level, a lane-level multiclass equilibrium assignment model is built to predict traffic flow distribution among lanes on both longitudinal and lateral locations regarding AVDL deployment plan. In the upper level, a 0-1 integer programming model is established to obtain the optimal deployment plan of the AVDL with minimal total travel time (TTT). Additionally, a problem-specific heuristic-based adaptive large neighborhood search algorithm is developed to solve the problem. The advantages of the proposed model are validated in North-South Elevated Expressway, Shanghai, China. Results indicate that the proposed framework outperforms existing methods in terms of TTT reduction. Finally, sensitivity analysis demonstrates the robustness of the developed method in reducing the TTT under different headways, demand levels, and OD distributions.
structured_info.methodology: The study proposes a bi-level optimization model. The lower level involves a lane-level multiclass equilibrium assignment model to predict traffic flow distribution. The upper level is a 0-1 integer programming model to optimize AVDL deployment. A heuristic-based adaptive large neighborhood search algorithm is developed to solve the problem.
structured_info.conclusion: The proposed framework enables optimal deployment of AVDLs considering both longitudinal and lateral locations, reducing total travel time (TTT) more effectively than existing methods. The framework is robust under varying conditions such as different headways, demand levels, and OD distributions.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: The paper presents a framework for optimizing the deployment of autonomous-vehicle-dedicated lanes (AVDLs) on expressways, considering both longitudinal and lateral locations to minimize total travel time (TTT).
Background_and_Motivation: The research addresses the challenge of integrating autonomous vehicles (AVs) into existing transportation systems dominated by human-driven vehicles (HVs).
The motivation stems from the need to maximize the benefits of AVs while minimizing disruptions caused by mixed traffic flows.
The authors argue that existing methods fail to account for lane-changing scenarios and network geometry, limiting their effectiveness in determining optimal AVDL locations.
The study links the specific problem of AVDL deployment to broader challenges in traffic management and efficiency.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, particularly in the areas of traffic flow optimization and autonomous vehicle integration.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include AVDLs, bi-level optimization, and lane-level traffic flow modeling.
The logical relationship involves using optimization to determine AVDL locations that minimize TTT while considering traffic flow dynamics.
Key assumptions include the classification of lanes as mixed or AVDL, and the behavior of vehicles in transition sections.
The paper contributes a novel framework for AVDL deployment, advancing knowledge in traffic management for mixed AV and HV scenarios.
Methodology: The core methods include a bi-level optimization model and a lane-level multiclass equilibrium assignment model.
The methodology is novel in its joint optimization of longitudinal and lateral AVDL locations and its applicability to real-world expressway scenarios.
Data sources include real-world traffic data from the North-South Elevated Expressway in Shanghai, with preprocessing steps to model traffic flows.
Experimental design is rigorous, with sensitivity analyses to validate robustness under various conditions.
The research follows a theoretical paradigm of traffic flow optimization, influencing its focus on efficiency metrics like TTT.
Results: Key results show that the proposed framework reduces TTT by up to 6.1% compared to existing methods.
The results are significant for traffic management, reliable under tested conditions, and stable across different AV penetration rates.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure begins with identifying gaps in existing methods, proposes a new framework, and validates it through case studies and sensitivity analyses.
Key steps include problem formulation, model development, algorithm design, and empirical validation.
Strengths include comprehensive validation and robustness testing; weaknesses may include assumptions about vehicle behavior in transition sections.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include the novel joint optimization approach and practical applicability to real-world expressways.
Limitations include assumptions about lane-changing behavior and the focus on expressways, which may not generalize to all road types.
The theoretical paradigm constrains conclusions to efficiency metrics, potentially overlooking other factors like safety or environmental impact.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within the discourse on AV integration and traffic management, contributing a new optimization framework.
The authors use technical terminology and a formal tone, building authority through citations to prior work in traffic engineering and optimization.
Conclusions_and_Implications: The main conclusion is that the proposed framework effectively optimizes AVDL deployment, reducing TTT more than existing methods.
Future research could explore extensions to urban roads and incorporate additional factors like safety and environmental impact.
